questions.text: A general physician at district hospital observed that many people of locality are suffering from parasitic diseases.As prevalence is high he requested RMO for rapid diagnostic kits. Which of the following pairs for rapid antigen detection test for parasites is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

P.falciparum - pLDH is inappropriate because pLDH is not the most specific antigen for P. falciparum malaria.

  • The more specific marker for falciparumwould be HRP-2 (Histidine Rich Protein 2).
  • While pLDH can be used for detecting malaria in general, it is less specific for falciparumalone.
  • RAT (Rapid antigen detection test) is a common procedure for diagnosis of parasitic infection employing species-specific antigen in which monoclonal antibodies against the specific antigen are bound to the membrane.
  • Lateral flow of the sample will result in binding of antigen to specific monoclonal antibodies resulting in color band formation.

Explanation of other options:

Leishmania donovani - rk 39(Option A): Leishmania donovani is the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis (also known as kala-azar).

The rk39 antigen is widely used for rapid diagnostic tests for Leishmania donovani. This antigen is a recombinant protein that is highly specific to Leishmania donovani and is often used in serological tests to detect antibodies or antigens in blood or other samples.

Wuchereria bancrofti - Og4C3(Option B): Wuchereria bancrofti is a parasitic worm responsible for causing lymphatic filariasis (also known as elephantiasis).

The Og4C3 is a specific antigen that is secreted by the adult worms and can be detected in the blood of individuals infected with Wuchereria bancrofti.

Entamoeba histolytica - galactose lectin antigen(Option D): Entamoeba histolytica is the parasite responsible for amoebiasis, including dysentery and liver abscesses.

The galactose lectin antigen is an important surface protein involved in the parasite's adhesion to host tissues and is often targeted in diagnostic tests for histolytica. The pathogenic Entamoeba histolytica can be distinguished from the non-pathogenic Entamoeba dispar by detecting the Galactose/N-acetyl-D-galactosamine inhibitable lectin (Gal/GalNAc lectin) antigen in stool samples.

questions.text: A diagnostic test involves feeding a laboratory-reared, starved vector on a patient suspected of having a parasitic infection. Later, the vector is dissected and examined for the presence of the parasite. This method is most commonly used in the diagnosis of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This diagnostic method is known as Xenodiagnosis.

  • Xenodiagnosis involves using a laboratory-reared and starved vector (such as an insect), which is then allowed to feed on a suspected patient.
  • After feeding, the insect is examined for the presence of the parasite.
  • The technique is particularly useful for detecting parasites that circulate in low numbers in the bloodor in cases where other diagnostic methods may not be sensitive enough.
  • Not only parasites, it is also useful to diagnose many bacterial infections like Rickettsial infections and Lyme disease caused by Borrelia.
  • Chagas disease is a parasitic infection caused by T.cruzi transmitted by reduviid bugs.
  • This is the method of choice in suspected Chagas disease, if other examinations are negative, especially during the early phase of the disease onset.
  • The reduviid bugs are reared in a trypanosome-free laboratory and starved for 2 weeks.
  • They are then fed on the patient's blood. If trypomastigotes are ingested, they will multiply and develop into epimastigotes and trypomastigotes, which can be found in the feces of the bug 2 weeks later.
  • Traditionally used to diagnose Chagas disease, it was also used previously for diagnosis of Babesia and filariasis.
  • However, with development of newer diagnostic techniques like molecular tests, it is now rarely used for other infections.

Explanation of other options:

Amoebiasis(Option B):It is caused by Entamoeba Histolytica and has a direct fecal-oral transmission cycle. There is no role for feeding a vector on a patient.The standard method is microscopic examination of stool samples for cysts or trophozoites

Malaria(Option C) :It is caused by Plasmodium species.The gold standard is microscopic examination of blood smears (Giemsa stain) from the patient to visualize the parasites inside red blood cells. Rapid antigen tests and PCR are also used.

Kala-azar (Visceral Leishmaniasis) (Option D): It is caused by the Leishmania donovani complex.The definitive diagnosis is made by demonstrating the amastigote forms of the parasite in tissue samples from the patient, most commonly from splenic or bone marrow aspirates. Serological tests (like the rK39 rapid test) are also widely used.

questions.text: Match following parasites with their mode of infection..
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The "mode of infection" for a parasite refers to the specific mechanism or route by which the infectious stage of the parasite enters the human host to establish an infection.
  • Naegleria fowleriis primarily contracted when water containing the amoeba enters by penetrating nasal mucosa (usually from activities like swimming or diving in warm freshwater). (Option A,C and D ruled out)
  • The amoeba travels from the nose to the brain through the olfactory nerve(the nerve responsible for smell), causing inflammation and damage to brain tissue.
  • It cannot be contracted through drinking contaminated water or person-to-person transmission.
  • Entamoeba histolytica is an amoeba and the infection is acquired through ingestion of contaminated food or water.This is the most common mode of infection for intestinal parasites. The infectious stage (cyst, egg) is shed in the feces of an infected host and contaminates food, water.
  • Ancylostoma duodenale is a nematode in which infective filariform larvae are present in soil. When a person walks barefoot on faecally contaminated soil, larvae enter the body through skin penetration.
  • Wuchereria bancrofti is a nematode in which infection acquired through bite of infected mosquito-species of Culex like C.fatigans or C.quinquefasciatus.The infectious filariform larvaeare deposited on the skin by the mosquito and enter through the bite wound.

questions.text: In the context of the life cycle of parasites, identify an odd one?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The odd one here is Entamoeba histolytica as it follows the direct life cycle where only one species of  host is required to complete the life cycle.
  • There are 2 types of development life cycle of parasites: Direct and Indirect.
    • Indirect life cycle: It requires 2 different host species to complete development in order to become infective. L.donovani (option A), T.brucei (option B) and P.vivax (option D) require a sand fly, Tsetse fly or anopheles mosquito as an invertebrate host respectively.
    • Direct life cycle: histolytica (option C) is a parasite where only one species of host (human) is required to complete the life cycle.

Parasite having direct life cycle (requiring no intermediate host):

Parasites having indirect life cycle requiring one intermediate host and one definitive host:

questions.text: A person who has taken bath dips in the holy water of a river with his nose and mouth closed by fingers, now afraid of acquiring one of parasitic infections. He should screen himself for which parasitic infection if symptoms develop?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The infective forms of many parasites are present in contaminated water. They either enter through direct skin penetration (S.haematobium), nasal mucosal penetration (Naegleria fowleri), ingestion of cyclops (D.medinensis) or ingestion of aquatic vegetation (F.hepatica).
  • The infectious stage of Schistosoma haematobium, the cercariae, are released by freshwater snails. These larvae actively penetrate the intact skinof anyone in the water. In the given clinical scenario the person closes his nose and mouth with fingers which is ineffective against the cercariae of schistosoma and thus he should get himself screened if he develops any of the symptoms.
  • Schistosoma haematobium causes Urogenital Schistosomiasis(formerly called Bilharzia).
  • The adult worms live in the venous plexus around the bladder and urinary tract. The primary symptom is hematuria(blood in the urine). Chronic infection causes inflammation, fibrosis, and calcification of the bladder and ureters, and is a major risk factor for squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

Explanation of other options:

Fasciola hepatica (Liver Fluke) (Option A): It causes Fascioliasis, also known as sheep liver fluke infection. The mode of Infection is ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic plants.Since the mouth was closed and no plants were eaten, this route of infection is effectively blocked.

Dracunculus medinensis (Guinea Worm) (Option B): It causes Dracunculiasis, also known as Guinea worm disease.The mode of Infection is ingestion of water containing infected copepods.Since the person closed his mouth the oral route was blocked. Infection is highly unlikely without swallowing the water.

Naegleria fowleri (Option C): It causes Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM). This is a rapidly fatal infection of the brain. The amoeba enters via the nose and infects the brain tissue. Symptoms start with severe headache, fever, and vomiting, and rapidly progress to stiff neck, seizures, and coma. If done effectively the person's action would be protective against the parasite.

questions.text: An intermediate host whose presence may be required for the completion of a parasite's life cycle but in which no development of the parasite occurs is -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paratenic host:
    • An organism that harbors the sexually immature parasite (larva) but is not necessary for the parasite's developmental cycle to progress.
    • Its function is to bridge an ecological gap, helping the parasite get from one obligatory host to the next.
    • Eg: fish for plerocercoid larva of Diphylobothrium latum.

Explanation of other options:

Reservoir host (Option B): An organism that harbors a pathogen but suffers no ill effects, responsible for continued existence of parasites in the area. Such a host harbors the parasite and acts as an important source of infection to other susceptible hosts.

E.g. A dog is the reservoir host of hydatid disease.

Accidental host (Option C): An organism that generally does not allow transmission to the definitive host, thereby preventing the parasite from completing its development. This is a host that is not part of the parasite's normal life cycle.

Eg: man is an accidental host for cystic echinococcosis.

Definite host (Option D):This is the host in which the parasite reaches sexual maturity and reproduces sexually.Significant development does occur in this host. It is the primary, obligatory host in the life cycle.

E.g. Humans are the definitive host for Plasmodium malaria parasites.

questions.text: One of Koch's postulates states that re-introduction of microbial agents must produce the same disease as before. Trypanosomes are known for not following the postulate. By which mechanism trypanosomes disobey the Koch postulate-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Koch's postulate in question implies that a single, specific microbial agent consistently causes a specific disease. Trypanosomes, specifically Trypanosoma brucei species responsible for African Sleeping Sickness, violate this principle through antigenic variation.

Trypanosoma brucei evades host immunity through variant surface glycoproteins (VSGs), also called variant-specific surface antigens (VSSAs). The parasite's surface is covered by a dense VSG coat, which elicits a strong antibody response that clears most parasites. However, a small subpopulation (≈1 in 10‚Å∂) spontaneously switches to a different VSG gene, producing a new surface antigen. The existing antibodies cannot recognize this new variant, allowing the parasite population to expand and cause another wave of parasitemia.

This cycle of antigenic switching explains the recurrent fever spikes followed by apyrexia seen in African trypanosomiasis. Importantly, if parasites from an early infection wave are reintroduced into the same host, they would be neutralized immediately by pre-formed antibodies. The relapsing illness depends on the sequential emergence of novel VSG variants.

Explanation of other options:

Masking of antigen (Option A) : Masking of antigen is used by schistosomes as an immune evasion mechanism.

Intracellular habitat (Option B) : Trypanosomes are primarily extracellular pathogens, found in the blood, lymph, and later cerebrospinal fluid. They do not have a significant intracellular phase like Leishmaniaor Plasmodium.

Resistance to phagocytosis (Option D) :the VSG coat may contribute to resisting certain host defenses, the fundamental reason for disobeying Koch's postulate is the change in the antigenic identity, not a general resistance to a single immune mechanism like phagocytosis. Leishmania inhibits phagocytosis.

questions.text: A first-year pathology resident is given exercise to demonstrate various parasitic infections from peripheral blood smear (PBS). He should look for following parasites in PBS EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The first year resident would observe that unlike blood protozoa such as Plasmodium or Babesia, Schistosoma haematobiumis not seen on routine peripheral blood smear (PBS). The adult worms inhabit the venous plexus of the urinary bladder, and their eggs penetrate the bladder wall to be excreted in urine, which is the diagnostic specimen. Although schistosomes reside in vesical and pelvic venous plexuses, they are never demonstrable in peripheral blood because they remain confined to the capillaries of internal organs.

Explanation of other options:

  • Leishmania (Option A):In Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar), the amastigote form of the parasite can be found inside monocytes and macrophages in the peripheral blood, especially in a buffy coat While not always numerous, it is a definitive diagnostic finding.
  • Trypanosomes: (Option B)The trypomastigote form of both Trypanosoma brucei (African Sleeping Sickness) and Trypanosoma cruzi (Chagas disease) circulates freely in the peripheral blood and is the primary form used for microscopic diagnosis.
  • Babesia (Option D):The trophozoite form of Babesia species infects red blood cells and is readily visible on a peripheral blood smear, often showing characteristic tetrads (Maltese crosses) and multiple rings per cell.

questions.text: A microbiologist received a stool sample for examination as the patient has had diarrhea since 1 week. He observed that there are parasitic eggs in the sample and they are greenish yellow stained. Which of the following parasitic eggs is most likely to be bile-stained in the stool examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The eggs of Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) are distinctive because they are released from the uterus into the intestinal lumen through an operculumwhile still inside the small intestine.
  • This early release exposes them to bile, producing their characteristic greenish-yellow to yellow-brown staining. Among intestinal parasites, D. latum is therefore the most likely to have bile-stained eggs, unlike other helminths whose eggs are not subjected to significant bile exposure during passage through the gut.

Explanation of other options:

  • Enterobius vermicularis (Pinworm) (Option A): Pinworm eggs are colorless and transparent. They are not bile-stained because the female worm lays them directly on the perianal skin, not in the intestine, so they never come into contact with bile.
  • Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf Tapeworm) (Option C):The eggs of H. nana are also colorless or very pale. They are released within the intestine when the proglottid disintegrates, but they have a characteristic clear, outer membrane and an inner embryophore with polar filaments, without the bile-staining seen in D. latum.
  • Trichuris trichiura (Whipworm)(Option D): Whipworm eggs have a characteristic brownish, barrel-shaped appearance with bipolar plugs. This brown color comes from their own shell, not from bile staining. They are passed in the stool in an unembryonated state and their color is intrinsic.

questions.text: Which of the following require two intermediate hosts for completion of life cycle?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Clonorchis sinensis, the Chinese liver fluke, requires two intermediate hosts to complete its life cycle:

  1. First Intermediate Host:A specific species of freshwater snail. Inside the snail, the parasite undergoes several larval stages (sporocyst, redia, cercaria).
  2. Second Intermediate Host:A freshwater fish. The cercariae released from the snail encyst as metacercariae in the muscles of the fish.

Humans, the definitive host, become infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing the metacercariae.

Most trematodes (except Schistosomes) require two intermediate hosts to complete their life cycle. Other examples include:

  • Diphyllobothrium latum - cyclops (1st) & fish (2nd)
  • Paragonimus westermani- snail (1st) & crab/crayfish (2nd)
  • Fasciola species – snail (1st) & aquatic plants (2nd)

Clonorchis sinensis

Explanation of other options:

Taenia saginata (Option A): This tapeworm, also known as the beef tapeworm, only requires one intermediate host: cattle. Humans are the definitive host and become infected by eating undercooked beef that contains the larval cysts.

Wuchereria bancrofti (Option C): This parasitic worm is responsible for lymphatic filariasis (also called elephantiasis). It requires only one intermediate host: the mosquito. The mosquito transmits the larvae to humans, where they mature in the lymphatic system.

Dracunculus medinensis(Option D): Known as the guinea worm, this parasite only requires one intermediate host: a tiny water flea. Humans become infected by drinking contaminated water containing the fleas. The larvae mature inside the human and emerge through the skin as the adult worm.

questions.text: Consumption of pork can lead to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trichinosis (Trichinellosis)is caused by the nematode Trichinella spiralis. Humans acquire the infection specifically by eating raw or undercooked pork (or wild game meat) containing the infectious larval cysts. When the meat is digested, the larvae are released into the small intestine, where they mature into adult worms.

Explanation of other options:

Cysticercosis (Option A) : This is caused by the larval stage of the pork tapeworm, Taenia solium. However, humans do not get cysticercosis from eating pork. They get it by accidentally ingesting T. solium eggs from fecal contamination. Eating undercooked pork gives you the adult intestinal tapeworm (taeniasis), not cysticercosis.

Toxoplasmosis (Option B) : Toxoplasmosis occurs due to consumption of oocyst which are excreted in cat feces.

Clonorchiasis (Option D) : Clonorchiasis is due to consumption of contaminated fish.

questions.text: Match following skin test used in parasitology with their disease
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • These are various skin tests which are useful for detection of parasitic infection.
  • Antigen is administered intradermally, if a patient has a previous infection, either an immediate reaction with wheal and flare or delayed hypersensitivity reaction with erythema and induration takes place.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the infective form?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The amastigote form is not typically the infective form for the parasites where it is found. It is the intracellular, replicative stage.

  • In Leishmania, the infective form transmitted by the sandfly is the promastigote. Once inside a human macrophage, the promastigote transforms into the non-motile, intracellular amastigoteto multiply.
  • In Trypanosoma cruzi(Chagas disease), the infective form in the triatomine bug's feces is the metacyclic trypomastigote. Once inside a human cell, it transforms into the amastigote to multiply.

The amastigote is the form that causes pathology and maintains the infection within the host, but it is not the form that is transmitted to a new host.

Explanation of other options:

  • Sporozoite (Option A):This is the infective form of the malaria parasite (Plasmodium species) that is injected by an infected Anopheles mosquito. It travels to the liver to initiate infection.
  • Oocyst (Option B): This can be an infective form. For coccidian parasites like Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora, and Isospora, the thick-walled, environmentally resistant oocyst is the stage that is shed in feces and is infectious when ingested by a new host.
  • Metacyclic trypomastigote (Option D): This is the infective form of Trypanosoma cruzi and Trypanosoma brucei. For T. cruzi, it is found in the reduviid bug's feces, for T. brucei, it is found in the salivary glands of the tsetse fly. It is the stage adapted to survive in and infect the mammalian host.

questions.text: The classification of protozoa into Sarcomastigophora, Ciliophora and Sporozoa is based on?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • In the traditional classification, protozoa were grouped primarily based on their organ of locomotion.
  • They were divided into four phyla:
    • Sarcomastigophora(subdivided into Sarcodina moving by pseudopodia, e.g., Entamoeba, and Mastigophora moving by flagella, e.g., Giardia)
    • Ciliophora(moving by cilia, e.g., Balantidium coli)
    • Sporozoa/Apicomplexa and Microspora(non-motile, lacking locomotor organelles in their mature stages, e.g., Plasmodium). This classical system, though now largely replaced by molecular phylogenetics, highlights locomotion as the key distinguishing feature.

Explanation of other options:

  • Method of reproduction (Option A):While reproduction (e.g., asexual binary fission, schizogony, sexual conjugation) varies among groups, it was not the primary defining characteristic for this high-level classification.
  • Nuclear character (Option C):All protozoa are eukaryotic and have a similar nuclear structure. While some, like the Ciliophora, have a unique nuclear dualism (macronucleus and micronucleus), this was a supporting feature, not the primary basis for the phylum's definition.
  • Location (Option D):The habitat (e.g., blood, intestine) is not a taxonomic characteristic for fundamental classification.

questions.text: A 35 year old male came with complaints of cough with sputum and blood. He frequently eats crab. Stool examination revealed that he has lung fluke infection which belongs to the Trematode family. The correct sequence of development in trematode is?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The given clinical scenario describes a classic case of Paragonimiasis (lung fluke infection) caused by Paragonimus westermani, which is a trematode. The life cycle of all trematodes (flukes) follows a specific sequence of larval development within the snail intermediate host and the environment.

The correct sequence is:(Option A, B and D are ruled out)

  • Miracidium:A ciliated, free-swimming larva that hatches from the egg in water and infects a specific snail species.
  • Sporocyst:The miracidium transforms into a sac-like sporocyst inside the snail.
  • Redia:The sporocyst produces the next generation, called rediae.
  • Cercaria:The rediae produce free-swimming cercariae, which have tails and emerge from the snail.
  • Metacercaria:The cercariae encyst in a second intermediate host (e.g., a crab or crayfish for Paragonimus) or on vegetation, losing their tails and becoming the infective metacercariae for the definitive host (humans).

Trematodes have humans or animals as definitive hosts. Eggs are released into the environment (e.g., water) and hatch into miracidia, which infect snails (first intermediate host) and develop into sporocysts. In most trematodes (except schistosomes), sporocysts produce rediae, which then become cercariae. Cercariae leave the snail, penetrate a second intermediate host (fish, crab, or aquatic vegetation), and encyst as metacercariae, the infective stage for definitive hosts.

questions.text: The microbiologist while examining the stool sample found some oocyst. From history and clinician provisional diagnosis he understood that the patient has Cryptosporidium infection. Which stain can demonstrate the oocysts of Cryptosporidium best:
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen (acid-fast) stain is one of the most common and effective stains used to identify Cryptosporidium oocysts in stool samples.

  • The oocysts of Cryptosporidium are acid-fast, meaning they retain the red dye (carbol fuchsin) even when decolorized with a strong acid. This property is due to their complex, robust oocyst wall.
  • Under the microscope, Cryptosporidium oocysts appear as bright pink to red spherical structuresagainst a blue or green counterstain background.
  • This stain is also used to detect other coccidian parasites like Cyclospora (which are variably acid-fast) and Isospora (which are consistently acid-fast).

Explanation of other options:

  • Trichrome stain and Iron Haematoxylin (Option A and D):These are excellent stains for visualizing the trophozoite and cyst stages of intestinal protozoa (like Giardia, Entamoeba) but they are not optimal for demonstrating the oocysts of coccidian parasites like Cryptosporidium, which do not stain well with these methods.
  • Modified Trichrome stain (Option B):The Modified Trichrome (or Ryan) stainis the standard for detecting the spores of microsporidia. The acid-fast stain is more specific and routinely used.

questions.text: A Broncho-alveolar lavage sample of an eosinophilic lung disease patient showed charcot-leyden crystals. Charcot leyden crystals are derived from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Charcot-Leyden crystalsare derived from eosinophils, a type of white blood cell involved in allergic reactions, parasitic infections, and asthma. (Option A, C and D ruled out)
  • These crystals are formed from the breakdown of eosinophil proteinslike major basic protein.
  • When eosinophils are activated or degranulate, their contents, including proteins and enzymes, can crystallize, forming the Charcot-Leyden crystals, which are typically seen in conditions like asthma, eosinophilic lung diseases, and parasitic infections particularly with Toxocara, Capillariasis, Ascariasis, or Fasciola.

questions.text: Protozoans are classified based on organ of locomotion. Usually cilia is used for adhesion but it is used for locomotion by which organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cilia are normally organs of adhesion in micro-organism.
  • Balantidium coli is the only ciliated protozoan that causes disease in humans. It uses cilia as its primary organ for locomotion. The coordinated beating of these numerous, hair-like cilia allows the trophozoite to move rapidly in its environment (the large intestine). It is also the largest protozoan parasite of humans.

Explanation of other options:

Trypanosoma cruzi (Option A): It is the causative agent of Chagas disease, uses a single flagellum for locomotion. It moves in a characteristic whip-like motion driven by the flagellum.

Giardia lamblia(Option C): It is the causative agent of giardiasis, uses flagella for movement. It has four pairs of flagella that help it move in a characteristic falling leaf

Entamoeba histolytica(Option D): This causes amoebiasis, moves by using pseudopodia (extensions of its cytoplasm), not cilia or flagella.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman presents with flu-like symptoms, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. She mentions having a recent exposure to cat feces while cleaning the litter box. Given the suspicion of a parasitic infection, the doctor advised Sabin-Feldman dye test. Sabin - Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario the patient's symptoms are suspicious of Toxoplasmosis.
  • The Sabin-Feldman dye test is a highly specific serological testfor detecting Toxoplasma gondii antibodies, primarily IgG, indicating past or chronic infection.
  • Principle:Live Toxoplasma tachyzoites take up alkaline methylene blue in the absence of antibodies. In the presence of patient antibodies and complement, the parasite membrane is altered, preventing dye uptake. Serum is mixed with live trophozoites, incubated with complement at 37°C for 1 hour, then stained with methylene blue. If >50% of trophozoites remain unstained, the test is positive.
  • Significance:Historically considered the gold standard, it is rarely used today due to technical complexity, requirement for live parasites, low sensitivity, and risk of false positives. Modern molecular and serological tests have largely replaced it.

Explanation of other options:

  • Entamoeba histolytica (Option A):Diagnosis is made by microscopic identification of trophozoites or cysts in stool, antigen detection tests, or serology like ELISA, but not the Sabin-Feldman dye test.
  • Toxocara canis (Option B):Diagnosis of visceral larva migrans is typically made by serological tests like an ELISA using the Toxocara excretory-secretory (TES) antigen.
  • Balantidium coli (Option D):Diagnosis is made by microscopic identification of the large, ciliated trophozoites or cysts in stool samples.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Stool examination reveals the presence of oocysts. The patient has a history of traveling to regions with poor sanitation. Given the suspicion of a parasitic infection, which of the following parasites would not be demonstrated using a modified acid-fast stain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The modified acid-fast stain (e.g., Modified Ziehl-Neelsen or Kinyoun stain) is specifically used to identify the oocysts of certain coccidian parasites based on their ability to retain the red carbol fuchsin dye.

  • Blastocystis hominisis not a coccidian parasite and does not form an acid-fast oocyst. It is a stramenopile (a type of protozoan). Its vacuolar form, which is the stage seen in stool, does not stain with the acid-fast method.It is best demonstrated in stool smear by giemsa or iron hematoxylin or trichrome stain.

Explanation of other options:

  • Cryptosporidium parvum (Option A):Its oocysts stain bright red (acid-fast positive) against a blue or green background. This is a primary diagnostic method.
  • Isospora belli (Option B):Its oocysts are also acid-fast positive, staining a uniform red color.
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis (Option C):Its oocysts are variable in their acid-fast staining, often appearing from light pink to deep red, and sometimes showing a "wrinkled" or crumpled cellophane appearance. They are demonstrable with this stain.
  • All the three mentioned parasites are causing severe protracted diarrhea in immunocompromised persons like AIDS patients.

choices.text: Patient is allowed to swallow a capsule containing coiled thread
Used for demonstration of giardia lamblia
Not used for obtaining eggs of Fasciola hepatica

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with persistent abdominal discomfort, bloating, and intermittent diarrhea. After a thorough workup, the physician suspects a possible infection with Giardia lamblia. To confirm the diagnosis, the patient undergoes the Enterotest (String test). Which of the following statements about the Enterotest is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Enterotest is a simple method to collect duodenal contents.(Option A ruled out)
  • The patient swallows a gelatin capsule containing a coiled nylon thread, with one end attached externally. (Option B ruled out) The capsule dissolves in the stomach, allowing the weighted string to reach the duodenum. After 3-4 hours, the thread is withdrawn, and secretions adhering to it are scraped and examined microscopically.
  • Traditionally used for detecting Giardia lamblia, the Enterotest can also collect Fasciola hepatica eggs, Strongyloides stercoralis larvae, and Isospora oocysts.(Option C ruled out)In heavy F. hepatica infections, eggs carried by bile into the duodenum can be retrieved via this method, especially when stool exams are negative. While not the primary diagnostic tool, it remains a valid alternative in selected cases.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with severe watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and bloating after a recent camping trip. His stool sample is sent for microscopic examination, and cysts are observed. Given the patient's symptoms and travel history, which of the following parasites is least likely to form cysts in its lifecycle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trichomonas vaginalis exists only as a trophozoite and lacks a cyst stage. Because trophozoites cannot survive outside the host, direct person-to-person transmission, primarily sexual, is required. This distinguishes it from protozoa like Entamoeba histolytica, E. coli, and Giardia lamblia, which have both trophozoite and cyst forms.
  • The absence of cysts makes T. vaginalis fragile outside the human host, and its lifecycle is entirely trophozoite-based.
  • The patient's symptoms of watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and bloating after a camping trip are typical of Giardiasis caused by Giardia intestinalis, which does form resistant cysts transmitted via contaminated water.

Explanation of other options:

  • Entamoeba coli (Option A): This is a non-pathogenic commensal amoeba that is commonly found in the human colon. It does form cysts, which are passed in the stool and are the infective form.
  • Entamoeba histolytica (Option B): This is the causative agent of amoebic dysentery and liver abscesses. It does form cysts, which are the infective stage responsible for transmission through contaminated food or water.
  • Giardia intestinalis (Option D): This is the most likely cause of the patient's illness and does form cysts. The cysts are environmentally stable and are the primary means of transmission, especially in settings like camping where water filtration may be inadequate.

choices.text: Common mode of infection is ingestion
Larva develops into adults in ectopic sites
Can also be caused by larva of S.stercoralis and A.lumbricoides in ectopic sites

questions.text: The following statement is incorrect about Visceral larva migrans
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The larvae do not develop into adults in ectopic sites.

  • In visceral larva migrans, the larvae of Toxocara (or other parasites) migrate through various tissues, causing inflammation and tissue damage, but they do not mature into adult worms in these sites.(Option A ruled out)
  • Humans acquire infection by ingesting embryonated eggsfrom soil contaminated with dog/cat feces.(Option B ruled out)
  • The larvae typically remain in the larval stageand may cause granulomas or other tissue reactions, but they do not undergo further development into adults in humans.
  • The adult worms only mature in their natural definitive hosts(e.g., dogs or cats for Toxocara).
  • Visceral larva migrans (VLM) or toxocariasis is a zoonotic infection usually caused by dog or cat ascarids of the Toxocara genus.
  • It is also seen in human nematodes like S.stercoralis and A.lumbricoides, when larvae of these parasites are not able to complete their normal development and enter ectopic sites.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with chronic gastrointestinal symptoms, including diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss. She has a history of frequent travel to tropical regions, where sanitation is poor. Stool examination reveals eggs and larvae of a parasitic infection. The patient is concerned about the possibility of reinfection due to autoinfection. Which of the following parasites is not associated with autoinfection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Auto infection is a feature of Taenia solium but not of Taenia saginata.
  • Due to unhygienic habits of not washing hands, a person having taeniasis due to T.solium can auto infect himself resulting in cysticercosis.
  • In Taneia saginata the Life cycle requires ingestion of cysticerci in undercooked beef.
  • Humans pass eggs → cattle act as intermediate host → cysticerci develop → humans reinfected only by consuming infected beef.

Explanation of other options:

H.nana(Option A ): It causes both internal and external autoinfection.Internal infection is due to eggs in the intestine hatch, penetrate mucosa and develop into larval stage (cysticercoid). External autoinfection is due to faeco-oral contamination due to unhygienic habits.

E.vermiculari(Option C): It has features of auto infection and retro infection.Retroinfection (eggs hatch on perianal skin, larvae migrate back into rectum), or ingestion of embryonated eggs under fingernails (fecal-oral reinfection).Causes pruritus ani, perianal dermatitis.

S.stercoralis(Option D): It can undergo auto infection (hyper infection syndrome) in persons with defective cellular immune response.Rhabditiform larvae in the intestine may transform into infective filariform larvae → penetrate colonic mucosa or perianal skin → cause internal autoinfection.

Key Takeaways:

MNEMONIC; CHEST for organisms causing auto-infection

  • C - CRYPTOSPORIDIUM
  • H - H.Nana
  • E - ENTEROBIUS
  • S - STRONGYLOIDES
  • T - T.SOLIUM

questions.text: Man is definitive host in following parasite -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the life cycle of Taenia solium, man is the definitive host and pig is the intermediate host.
  • The host, in which the adult parasite lives and undergoes sexual reproductionis called the definitive host,
  • The host, in which the larval stage of the parasite lives or asexual multiplicationtakes place is called the intermediate host.
  • In some parasites, two different intermediate hosts may be required to complete different larval stages. These are known as first and second intermediate hosts, respectively.
  • Adult worms live in the intestine of man, producing eggs which are expelled along with faeces.
  • Due to open defecation, eggs in the field become accessible to pigs in which larvae (cysticercus cellulosae) develop in muscles.
  • However, sometimes due to unhygienic practices (auto infection) and reverse peristalsis(vomiting), eggs can hatch in the intestine releasing hexacanth embryos which after penetrating the intestine can lodge in various tissues and develop a condition called cysticercosis.

Parasites with man as intermediate or secondary host:

  • Plasmodium spp.
  • Babesia spp.
  • Toxoplasma gondii
  • Echinococcus granulosus
  • Echinococcus multilocularis
  • Taenia solium
  • Spirometra spp.

Explanation of other options:

Plasmodium species(Option A): Female anopheles mosquito is the definitive host where sexual reproduction takes place.

Echinococcus granulosis(Option B): Dog is the definitive host while man acts as an intermediate host/accidental dead-end host where larval development (hydatid cyst) takes place.

Toxoplasma gondi (Option C):Cat is the definitive host where sexual reproduction takes place in this parasite and it causes toxoplasmosis in humans.
